Amazon (AMZN +1.1%) Web Services CEO Andy Jassy tweets in support of Apple CEO Tim Cook saying Bloomberg Businessweek should retract its report about malicious Chinese chips in Super Micro parts headed for U.S. tech and telecom giants.
Piper Jaffray says Instagram (FB +0.6%) comes out ahead of Snapchat (SNAP -0.1%) in popularity with teenagers.
Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) is down 1.49% after announcing that it plans to raise $2B more in debt to fund content acquisitions and potentially make M&A moves.
Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) CEO Elon Musk says that "many" Model S and Model X interior configurations won't be available after November 1.
Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) is up 2.9% on the day and sits comfortably off its session low following the WSJ story of a FBI probe.
Facebook (FB -2.3%) has issued an update on what it called "coordinated inauthentic behavior" originating in Iran.
Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) is up 2.1% on the day amid a broad market downturn.
Facebook (FB -3%) has discovered more activity in a disinformation campaign tied to Iran, Reuters reports.
A few analysts shift targets after Alphabet’s (GOOG -3.9%) revenue miss but, as with Amazon, the overall reaction was generally a shrug.
Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) shares are down 7.6% premarket after yesterday’s revenue miss, but the reaction from analysts is mostly a collective shrug.
Chancellor Philip Hammond will introduce a digital services tax from April 2020 following a consultation and says it will target “established tech giants” instead of startups.

Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) is down another 3.95% as investors dig into valuation questions following Amazon's post-earnings slide and last week's dive by The Wall Street Journal into the streamer's culture.
Facebook (FB +3.9%) is pulling its Workplace business offering into a separate domain space to mollify customers that might be skittish over a series of bad security developments.
UBS thinks Apple (AAPL +3.1%) will ship around 24M Apple Watches this year including the Series 1, Series 3, and some Series 4 sales.
Credit rating agency Moody’s says Britain’s proposed “digital services tax” would reduce the cash flow of tech giants for years to come and reduce the benefits from the U.S. tax cuts.
In a new filing, Microsoft (MSFT -2.3%) says it has made $1.3B in cash payments related to its GitHub acquisition.
Amazon (AMZN -2.5%) strikes a deal with Apple (AAPL -2.4%) to sell its products directly through the e-commerce platform.
Apple (AAPL -1.8%) suppliers see red this morning after Skyworks Solutions printed a weak Q4 guidance on premium smartphone softness and BofAML downgraded the company on iPhone uncertainty.
Instinet raises its Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) target from $1,990 to $2,050, a 20% upside to Friday’s close.
Short-seller Andrew Left of Citron Research covered his short position on Facebook (FB -2.4%), Reuters reports, and it's all due to the power of Instagram.
Facebook (FB -2.4%) will cooperate with a French investigation into human moderation vs. algorithm-powered moderation, TechCrunch says.
Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) is down 4.3% on the day and it's possible that investors may be reacting to the flurry of EV news coming out of Germany.
Noted Apple (AAPL -5%) analyst Ming-Chi Kuo cuts his iPhone XR  shipment estimates from 100M to 70M through September 2019.

Longbow Research says its Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) checks indicate iPhone order cuts of 20% to 30% mainly for the XR and XS Max, which will be partially offset by order increases for the 8, 8 Plus, and older models.
Amazon (AMZN +2.2%) confirms that it selected D.C. and NYC for its split HQ2.
It's no HQ3, but Amazon.com (AMZN +1.6%) will add a major investment in Nashville, Tenn., as its new East Coast hub of operations, according to Reuters.
Goldman Sachs analyst Rod Hall cuts his Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) target from $222 to $209 and reiterates a Neutral rating.
Amazon (AMZN -4.3%) continues to use open-source software to build out AWS despite tensions with the open-source community, according to The Information.

Facebook's (FB -5.6%) plumbing new 2-year lows as the stock heads for its worst month in nearly five years, and angel investor Jason Calacanis for one thinks these are crisis times for the iconic social network.
Apple's (AAPL -3.7%) Tim Cook responds to criticism that the company takes billions from Google (GOOG -2.8%)(GOOGL -2.9%) while saying Apple sells products, not customer data.

Elon Musk tweets that Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) might be interested in working with Daimler (OTCPK:DDAIF) on an electric Sprinter. He says the company will inquire about partnering on the "great van" with the Mercedes nameplate.
Amazon's (NASDAQ:AMZN) Alexa Mobile Accessory Kit is now widely available to developers particularly those making Bluetooth headphones, headsets, and wearables.
Goldman Sachs analyst Rod Hall maintains a Neutral rating on Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) but drops its target from $209 to $182.
Apple (AAPL -0.1%) considered a connected TV dongle for its upcoming streaming service, according to The Information sources.
U.S. consumers spent $31.9B shopping online in the first 20 days of this month, up 17% Y/Y, according to Adobe Analytics data.
Facebook (FB +2.8%) is appealing a fine of £500,000 (about $639K) it received from UK regulators over the Cambridge Analytica scandal.
Rosenblatt analyst Jun Zhang reiterates a Neutral rating on Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) and a $200 target but thinks iPhone XR sales improved during China's Singles' Day holiday.
Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) wants to expand Amazon Pay to brick-and-mortar merchants, according to The Wall Street Journal.
Patrick Gaspard, the head of George Soros' philanthropic foundation Open Society, calls for congressional oversight on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) hiring opposition firm Definers.
Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) will offer subsidies to mobile operators in Japan to allow for iPhone XR discounts due to underwhelming sales.
Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) is the latest company to get a "Trump dip," as President Trump suggests consumers could handle a tariff put on iPhones and laptops imported from China.

Facebook (FB +3.1%) has disbanded a "War Room" that it was showing off to reporters just two months ago as part of an effort to demonstrate its seriousness in tackling issues including election misinformation, Bloomberg says.
Russia has filed charges to fine Google (GOOG, GOOGL) -- though not much -- for failing to go along with government censorship on banned websites.
YouTube (GOOG -0.6%, GOOGL -0.6%) is pulling back from scripted content output, a reversal of a strategy that pushed a premium subscription tier, The Hollywood Reporter says.
Amazon (AMZN +0.4%) Web Services begins using more efficient ARM-based server chips with the AWS Graviton Processors announced at the re:Invent conference.
Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) Web Services revenue could reach $71B by 2022, according to Jefferies analyst Brent Thill after attending this year's re:Invent conference.
Canaccord Genuity maintains a Buy rating but cuts its Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) target from $250 to $225 (24% upside) after surveys "indicated soft smartphone demand with disappointing initial XR sales."
Tesla (TSLA +2.7%) hit a goal of producing 1K Model 3s in a single day, according to an update from Electrek.

Facebook (FB +2%) is pursuing a strategy with upstart India wireless provider Reliance Jio to tap fast growth in the world's fastest-growing major Internet market, via inexpensive phones that have come to be known in rural areas as "WhatsApp phones."
A commission appointed by President Trump recommends that the U.S. Postal Service hike its rates for shipping packages.
Apple (AAPL -2.1%) execs moved some marketing staff from other projects to focus on boosting iPhone sales, according to Bloomberg.

Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) is up 1.3% on the day, despite a day of broad market declines. A positive note from Wolfe Research on margin potential and price target bump on shares to $430 (18% upside) could be helping to bring in some buyers.
UBS maintains a Buy rating on Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) but cuts the target from $225 to $210.
Morgan Stanley cuts its Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) price target from $253 to $236.
Jefferies upgrades Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) to a Buy rating from Hold on confidence that the company's balance sheet is improving and productivity is cycling higher.
The tech-heavy Nasdaq creeps up to a gain in early afternoon trading as the Dow and S&P 500 pare earlier losses.

Amazon (AMZN -1.2%) is launching its first private label line of toys for toddlers and kids. TJI Research spotted the AmazonBasics product pages for some products, though shipping isn't yet available.
Cowen analyst John Blackledge calls Amazon (AMZN +0.8%) his best idea for 2019.
DZ Bank sees risk with Netflix (NFLX +0.7%) as new streaming competitors arrive next year.

Facebook (FB +3.1%) and videogame maker ZeniMax have settled a lawsuit where the social-media giant was accused to stealing ZeniMax's secrets and technology for use in Oculus virtual-reality products.
Adobe (NASDAQ:ADBE) shares gain 0.4% aftermarket on Q4 results that narrowly beat EPS and missed revenue estimates. Q1 guidance has revenue of $2.54B and EPS of $1.60.
Adobe Systems (NASDAQ:ADBE): Q4 Non-GAAP EPS* of $1.90 beats by $0.02; GAAP EPS* of $1.48 beats by $0.02.
Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) Web Services has been replacing some of its Juniper Networks (NYSE:JNPR) routers and switches with in-house hardware, according to The Information sources.
Piper Jaffray cuts its Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) price target from $250 to $222 saying that recent supplier guidance cuts suggest "global unit uptake has not met expectations."
Wired magazine posts a deep dive into Tesla's (NASDAQ:TSLA) year of production hell in a new article that details the pressures of the Model 3 production ramp.
Robert W. Baird lifts its price target on Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) to $465 from $411 on what it sees as positive catalysts for the EV company ahead amid a changing narrative.
A U.S. tribunal will review a ruling that said an Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) iPhone import ban was not in the public interest even if the devices violate Qualcomm (NASDAQ:QCOM) patents.
D.A. Davidson maintains a Buy rating on Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) but cuts the price target from $290 to $280.
Pivotal Research maintains a Hold rating on Adobe (NASDAQ:ADBE) and lowers the target from $254 to $252 after earnings.
Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) wants to enter the pay TV business by selling subscriptions to cable networks like HBO and Showtime, which users could watch through Facebook's apps.

Noted Apple (NASDAQ:AAPL) analyst Ming-Chi Kuo cuts his Q1 iPhone shipment estimates by 20% to between 38M and 42M. Kuo expects 205M to 210M shipments in 2018 and a 5% to 10% drop in 2019 to 188M to 194M.
Bernstein analyst Todd Juenger maintains an Outperform rating for Netflix (NASDAQ:NFLX) but lowers the target from $465 to $421.
U.S. stock markets start strongly, led by industrial goods (+1.6%), tech (+1.1%), and financial (+1.0%).
Morgan Stanley sees the rally in Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) running out of steam shortly.

Facebook (NASDAQ:FB) shares are down 4.8% on plans to develop cryptocurrency for WhatsApp and a downgrade from German broker DZ Bank, which shifts FB from Hold to Sell and drops its target from $145 to $115.

Responding to a comment on Twitter, Elon Musk over the weekend said Tesla (NASDAQ:TSLA) will "cover the tax credit difference" for those customers for whom production delays mean they won't receive their cars until next year.
Amazon (NASDAQ:AMZN) is among the companies the SEC is pressing to disclose more revenue information to investors, according to WSJ sources.
Chinese companies urge employees to boycott (NASDAQ:AAPL) following the U.S. arrest of Huawei's CFO, according to Nikkei Asian Review.
Elon Musk tweets that Tesla's (NASDAQ:TSLA) Supercharger coverage will extend to all of Europe next year.
"Backing up the sleigh," on Facebook (NASDAQ:FB), tweets Andrew Left.
